newsitem.title: USA: U.S. crude imports stalled as Sep business ends.
newsitem.headline: U.S. crude imports stalled as Sep business ends.

text.p: Foreign crude activity into the U.S. was quiet again Wednesday, remaining aloof while end-September business worked its way out, traders said.
Barrels from Latin American were only at talking levels, since there seemed to be no interest for doing trades.
Crude brokers said Cano Limon was talked at a $1.65-$1.75 discount to October West Texas Intermediate/Cushing, while Cusiana offers firmed to talk at parity to October WTI.
October WTI/Cushing was around $21.70-$21.75 by the close, off around 35 cents from Tuesday's closing ranges.
Players were watching developments off the Mexican coast, as Tropical Storm Dolly forced closure of three large ports.
State oil company Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex) said it was forced to shut Pajaritos, Dos Bocas and Cayo Arcas ports on the Gulf of Mexico in preparation for possible damage.
A decision by the Ecuadorean government to revise all contracts with foreign companies with operations in the country, has had no impact on the market, traders said.
The head of the state oil company Petroecuador said each firm's contract would be revised for the benefit of the sate.
On the spot Brent market for the U.S., there remained only one cargo seen heading west for September. Traders said talk was quiet by the lack of arbitrage opportunities.
